author: klarkc
title: Pure-Vue: Vue to PureScript bridge
description: The entry barrier to build quality dapps on Cardano is high, one of the reasons are the missing of familiar frameworks for majority of the web-developers.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer suggests integrating PureScript, a language similar to Haskell, into Vue. The proposer suggests PureScript is widely used to build Cardano Dapps. However, no supporting evidence is provided for that. As a developer on Cardano, I primarily use ReactJs for the front-end and it has proven to be an effective framework when used with the cardano-serialization-lib for building transactions that are then sent to the node. There might exist a niche developer group who prefer to use PureScript, but then it is not clear why would they would want to use Vue (rather than ReactJs)  which, as the proposer suggests, is the third most popular framework.  I struggle to see how this would bring new developers to Cardano and how it would improve the experience of developers already on Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1: Walker Leite is the developer behind the proposal. He provides a short bio about himself, but there are no social media links to verify his experience besides Github. The skillset for the second developer, that he still need to hire, is provided.  Walker would deliver the bridge between PureScript and JavaScript and the additional developer would develop the link between Haskell and PureScript. A timeline is provided and broken down into four quarters. During the first quarter, the proposer will implement a proof-of-concept. In the second quarter he will build an Isomorphic API. In the third quarter, he will improve the API and improve tooling in the fourth quarter.  From the timeline, it is unclear which part will be delivered by Walker and which the other developer would deliver.  The budget is sized as an annual salary for the developer $60,000 per year.  For two developers the total budget is $120,000.  This works out to $5,000 per month salary, which is competitive for a Haskell developer and about average compared to other proposals I have reviewed so far (30+).  The proposer highlights several risks. The main ones are technical difficulties during the implementation and to mitigate it, he will implement the prototype first. The other risk is related to the possible lack of adoption, which he aims to mitigate with community outreach on community channels. The project doesn't list the second developer and lacks implementation details; therefore, I struggle to justify whether the project will deliver on its intentions.
f6_assessments.q2: The roadmap is provided with milestones over 1 year with quarterly checkpoints.  A good amount of KPIs are included to track the number of downloads, unique visitors, watches and contributors as well as the ratio of issues closed and the number of commits.  There is a clear statement on the success of the project which is an engaged community building Dapps using Vue and PureScript on the front-end and Haskell with PureScript on the backend. There is no mention on the frequency of KPIs or the channels for communicating these KPIs to the community. I think there's a good chance that Community will be able to audit the deliverable, given that development will happen on GitHub, and there's a good detail on KPIs that will be monitored.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal would try to build a bridge between Vue and PureScript (Haskell-like language for web applications), to allow the large universe of existing JavaScript-savvy DApp developers to deploy on Cardano. While being experimental, it is a very interesting idea and has the potential for large impact on our developer ecosystem. As far as the brief from this Challenge Setting is concerned, it is an excellent fit and would contribute to all metrics that define success of the challenge. The only thing I like to have seen more of is reaching out to the developer community to fill some of the definition and skill gaps beforehand and show openness to collaborate and display the sense of community and conversations this challenge calls for.
f6_assessments.q1:
This proposer from southern Brazil is a graduate of the Plutus Pioneer program and has also studied Haskell and PureScript on his own, while being a full-time web developer. He plans to hire a more experienced Plutus developer to work on equal terms (getting paid half the budget requested). As this position is currently empty, it is a crucial success factor of this proposal, and some preliminary market analysis or backstop (getting commitment from MLabs or IOHK for example to provide initial support if the position proves hard to fill) would have been a great step to mitigate this risk. I would also have loved to see this risk discussed - instead of the very good discussion of risks involving the UX and finished product.
What is missing from the budget and feasibility discussion is the breakdown of working hours committed, to get a better feeling of how this project would fit with the full time work commitment of the proposer.
The milestones are very measured and sensible, but could have been complemented with a more detailed timeline and much more detail on testing and Cardano resources required.
f6_assessments.q2: By sharing his Github and LinkedIn profiles, being open about the missing Haskell expertise and allocating half of the budget to this vacancy shows the high commitment of this proposer to make the project a success and be transparent. I would still have liked to see much more detail about the steps necessary to fill the role, KPIs and milestones for the development process pre-launch, and ways to connect with existing builders and the many extremely helpful people in Catalyst who are already sharing Plutus and development resources. Weighing the very strong points of this proposal against the weaknesses let me conclude that currently this project is not highly likely to be delivered successfully and on time, but it may well be worth taking a leap of faith, or if not funded coming back to co-propose with an experienced Haskell/PureScript developer.

f6_assessments.q0: After reviewing your whole proposal, I'd like to provide an overview (this is the view of a non-technologist). Investors are unlikely to notice a proposal in which the risk presentation is longer than the solution’s introduction. I know you're well equipped to take on a lot of danger and figure out how to correct it, but your word "try" makes me wonder how likely you are to overcome the challenges (while they are still directly related to the technological features of the project). So, instead of putting too much in the main risk paragraph, you can rewrite your wording and include it in the solution introduction to explain how you plan to build an embedded domain-specific language to bridge Vue Composition API to PureScript language inside Vue single-file components. I know you aim to establish a PureScript bridge between Cardano and the developers, so please show me the bridge design in greater detail. I offer you four points because your suggestion is relevant to the challenge, but please improve the manner in which you present your proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
You meet the requirements by giving a thorough roadmap for the project's operations for the first four quarters. You have a budget and a biographical text. I admire your effort and accomplishments. However, I am still unsure about your budget and how you will select the best remaining team member. Because the work involves employees with expertise and experience in various fields (as stated in your proposal), I believe it is vital to include a paragraph in your detailed plan about "successfully identifying a developer with specific understanding in Haskell/PureScript."
Furthermore, I'm curious how you plan to cover equipment expenditures over a year, given that the USD 120,000 you need to invest is simply for the salaries of two developers. The fact that the team is incomplete and the budget is not detailed is likely to reduce investors' trust in you. So let's go a little more explicit about these.
f6_assessments.q2: Auditability is the final section of a proposal and has the fewest requirements, so it's simple to see why it's frequently the shortest. However, in this situation, you made it too brief and did not include enough detail. Aside from the KPIs you provide to measure the project's influence on the problem, I haven't seen you detail how and where you will provide project progress information, nor have you offered significant figures to determine the project's success. Investors always prefer real numbers over the phrase "number."

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aims to create a bridge, an embedded domain-specific language to connect PureScript with the Vue Composition API inside of single-file Vue components. The project will signifcantly ease the work of Vue developers using PureScript, which will also bring impact to Cardano ecosystem by bringing aforementioned developer into the system as developer from the ease given by the Pure-Vue. The plan is concise and clearly written. The proposal has also described a number of project risk, ranging from technical risks to risks related to developer acceptance. For each of those hazards, the proposer has a plan to mitigate it, though.
f6_assessments.q1: The milestones provided in four quarterly milestones across a year. The developer costs make up the majority of the budget breakdown, which I believe could be even further explained. The proposers might do better to list down each milestone along with an estimation of the completion time. The proposal provides in-depth details on the proposer's background and work experiences, additionally, with the proposers Github account, enabling voters to quickly assess the proposer's reliability.
f6_assessments.q2: This part of the proposal is very short yet sufficent, measuring the impact of the project and its progress. Project will be traceable through public Github repository activity, and the impact measured by the number of downloads and contributors, for example. They defined the success in a very absolute point, which is creating the dApps using Vue and PureScript successfully on the frontend, and Haskell or PureScript on the backend.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposed project aims to build a domain specific language in the hopes of attracting JavaSript developers familiar with Vue to a Haskell-like language, PureScript.

At first glance, this might sound like a compelling idea, but as it stands now, the proposal lacks the elements to convince that Haskell developers need to, or want to develop front end components, or that front end developers who want to learn Haskell or a language very similar to it will be attracted by the proposed domain specific language. 

Because, in accordance with the guiding questions of the Developer Ecosystem challenge, we need to figure out what are the the tools that we need to prioritize first, I think this is not the right time to invest in the development of this bridge. But ultimately that’s the beauty of Catalyst, the community can vote for the proposal if enough developers consider this to be a need, that’s why at this time I’m neutral about the potential impact of this project, as I think that running it through the voting app would give us the best indication if this is indeed a project that some developers believe we need.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer offers his GitHub profile as proof of his competencies, but as of now there doesn’t seem to be anything that matches the level of complexity of this project.
That certainly doesn’t mean the developer can’t build the deliverable, but it looks like it would be the first project this complex that he delivers.
What worries me slightly though, is that a second Haskell developer would need to be hired to complete the project,  but there is absolutely no indication the proposal has any hiring or management skills, something that in the current circumstance he would need to complete the project.

The budget presented is very simplistic, only two lines covering the pay for the two developers needed for a year at $60.000 each. The yearly pay for a Haskell developer is not very high, but perhaps it would have been a better idea to present the project broken down  into 2, 6 month, proposals, as to not request such a big investment from the community treasury at once.

The implementation plan presented offers a birds eye view of the work that would need to get done in the first year of this project, but it lacks detail or specificity.
f6_assessments.q2:
There are some elements not thoroughly explained or missing from the other parts of the proposal, but as it stands now the auditability section is by far the weakest part of the presentation. The KPIs presented are very generic and don’t include any actual numbers and could be easily interpreted any way the proposer wants, making the auditing of this project extremely subjective and hard. This is further complicated by the fact that the proposal itself is not very clear and overly broad at times, and you have the recipe for a project that could prove difficult to keep track of.

This is especially problematic given the relatively high investment the Cardano treasury would be making in this project.

solution: Build a bridge from an accessible JavaScript framework with a rich HTML syntax (Vue) to the closest Haskell syntax (PureScript).
experience: I am JavaScript web developer for the last 9 years, working mainly with Vue on frontend. I started studying Haskell and PureScript last year, this year I completed the plutus pioneer program. Now I'm developing Cardano DApps.
